newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila threatens to close down Boracay resorts.
newsitem.headline: Manila threatens to close down Boracay resorts.

text.p: The Philippine environment department on Tuesday threatened to close 102 resorts on the country's best known beach in a row over pollution.
The resorts in Boracay were given 30 days to explain why they should not be shut for operating without environmental clearance, the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) said.
Lying 450 km (280 miles) south of Manila, Boracay has clear blue waters and miles of powdery white sand and is considered by many as an "island paradise".

But last week that image was soiled when DENR Secretary Victor Ramos declared Boracay "a disaster area", saying human waste had leaked into the sea water, infecting it with coliform bacteria that causes diarrhoea, typhoid and skin diseases.
Ramos' announcement drew sharp protests from tourism officials who said the beach was as pristine as ever.

Boracay has since become the centre of a controversy, with newspaper columnists taking sides, some saying Ramos was right in warning people of the health risks at Boracay and others saying it would hit tourist arrivals in the country.
The DENR said show-cause notices would be served on another 100 establishments in the next few days.
There are more than 200 resorts in Boracay.
More than 200,000 foreign tourists visited Boracay last year.
